Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Carbon-Free and Binder-Free Cathode Configurations for High-Energy Lithium-Sulfur Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in battery technology have been the driving force for the development of new electric vehicles and renewable energy storage systems for the electric grid. New chemistries are needed that are superior to current battery systems for both performance and cost. Among the various alternatives, lithium-sulfur (Li/S) chemistries are the most promising next-generation energy storage technologies, as they lead to advantages such as high theoretical energy density, wide range of operational temperature, and low cost. However, fundamental research is needed on Li/S batteries to address issues including short cycle life, poor coulombic efficiency and self-discharge. The primary goal of this EAGER project is to introduce electrocatalytic porous current collectors in the Li/S battery, which will fundamentally alter electrochemical properties and overcome many current shortcomings. The critical insight gained can be applied to a broad range of materials and energy related research fields such as solar cells, redox flow batteries and fuel cells. The educational and outreach activities associated with the project include active participation of undergraduates from underrepresented groups in the research program and hands-on experiences to high school students through Wayne State's Mobile Energy Lab program.

The goal of this fundamental research project is to address low charging efficiency and short cycle life issues of Li/S batteries. The approach used is to confine the dissolved intermediate polysulfides within the cathode of the cell. The research is based on the hypothesis that the polysulfide-shuttle process in the Li/S cell can be controlled by using electrocatalysis driven kinetics and surface adsorption chemistries. The objective is to confine the dissolved intermediate polysulfides within the cathode of the cell while enhancing the intermediate's utilization and reaction rate using engineered porous catalytic current collectors with the electrocatalysts integrated in it. The PI will investigate the following proposed roles of the electrocatalyst: (i) adsorb dissolved intermediate polysulfides on the catalyst surface to prevent polysulfide shuttle process; (ii) accelerate the reaction kinetics for transforming intermediate polysulfides to lower order polysulfides; and (iii) convert end product of discharge process back to solid sulfur during the charge process to improve cycle life. This EAGER project introduces a new concept of electrocatalytic mitigation that could define a novel pathway towards designing carbon-free electrode configurations with outstanding electrochemical properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the most promising next-generation battery chemistries, lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery technology has gained attraction owing to its low cost, safety and higher theoretical energy density than conventional Li-ion batteries. However, Li-S batteries have several drawbacks such as short cycle life, poor coulombic efficiency, eventual poisoning of Li-anode, and high self-discharge. The primary underlying origin of these issues is the dissolution of lithium polysulfides into the electrolyte and their subsequent parasitic reactions on the Li anode surfaces. This NSF-funded effort took a novel approach based on catalysis principles, to confine the polysulfides within the pores of the current collectors of the Li-S battery, a key intellectual merit of this research. The project undertaken by the principal investigator, in collaboration with graduate and undergraduate student mentees, to re-configure the Li-S battery by transforming traditional planar current collectors into catalytically active sites for polysulfide conversion reactions has shown potential for reducing traditionally used inactive materials like binders and carbon additives in the cell construction (towards achieving high energy density). Some salient outcomes resulting from this effort include:

(i)             Discovery of novel Li-S battery configuration that can work without using traditional binders and carbon additives in the electrode preparation.

(ii)           Identification of potential electrocatalysts that can enhance the redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides.

(iii)         Development of catalytically active atomically thin two-dimensional (2D) materials and understanding their electrochemical properties in Li-S battery configuration.

(iv)         Discovery of novel membranes based on 2D materials that can limit the polysulfide migration towards the anode.

(v)           Demonstration of enhanced cycle life in a full cell lithium-ion sulfur battery configuration by combining electrocatalytic current collectors as a cathode and metallic lithium-free as an anode.

Broader impacts of this activity include the development of novel electrocatalyst based 2D materials which are useful for other energy technologies such as solar cells, redox flow batteries, fuel cells, etc. The project provided summer internship opportunities for students from diverse backgrounds and enabled hands-on experience for high school students through our Mobile Energy Lab program. The activity further provided a training opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students including members of underrepresented groups.
